Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
This movie is absolutely horrible. Now, vast majority of the people that have seen this did not read the book, but I did, and you wanna know how long this section of the book was? SIX PAGES, out of a 200 page book. I don't even know why Sauron was in this, he wasn't in the book at all, they made thorin look way more evil than he was, there was no romance between the elves- strike that, the elves didn't have a story at all in the book, and just overall... what the fuck. This is probably the worst trilogy of movies made from a book ever made, which is a shame because the original trilogy of LOTR was almost flawless, and that makes me disappointed. I see all these comments saying "best movie ever" which is just ridiculous.

In the chapter that has the battle, the lake towns people realize that if the dragon is dead they are entitled to the money in the mountain, not knowing the dwarves are still alive. A bunch of stuff happens and in the end the dwarves build a wall to the entrance of the mountain, and the Lake town allied with the elves, and they marched on. When they arrive all three parties discuss the treasure and how it will be distributed blah blah blah. At night Bilbo climbs down from the wall and gives the arkenstone to the humans and elves, to keep everyone from fighting. However, the goblins attack and all out war ensues, and Bilbo is ex communicated due to giving away the arkenstone. After a while the eagles show up, and Bilbo gets hit in the head with a rock and misses the rest of the battle. When he wakes, it's all over.

That's it, about six pages and they made a two and a half hour movie out of it. What scummy cash grab.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
Sorry this is so long but I just had to speak my mind...

I don't understand the hate on these movies even through everyone is entitled to their own opinion and I respect that. Stretching them out to three instead of two was the best decesion and you can understand why if you watch all of the behind the scenes in the extended addition (which is absolutely worth the hours upon hours it takes to watch :D).  Two films would not have been enough. Shoot, three barely is if you were to include every detail of the book. I know that is what many of us really want but I understand how hard that is to achieve. However these films I truly believed enhanced the book. I know Peter Jackson added in a lot that was not in the book. However I do not see those things as changes that hurt the story but additions that enhance it and help the viewers (especially ones who have not read the book) piece the story together. When your reading the book your OK with details being left out. But from a filmmakers point of view you can't have those gaps or it hinders the flow of the story. So Peter Jackson and his amazing crew filled it in. Everything they added was not blindly thrown in, it was carefully thought out and investigated by breaking down pieces of the Apendecies and then placed it. Not to mention time had to be added in for the fight sequences which are not elaborated in the book because it is almost impossible to have a written description of the battles. But for a film you need to draw the fights out to add to the energy. Legolas and Tauriel were the biggest debate. For me I loved them (although I am not a very critical person and is almost good with anything). To me they added to the storytelling about the Mirkwood elves and gave you a deeper attachment to Thranduil. Tauriel also provided a strong female presence and her and Killi hinted at the scene with Gimli and Gladriel thus expanding on the complicated relationship with Dwarves and Elves. Also who is to say that there wasn't a character like Tauriel amongst the woodland elves. Having her and Legolas split off to spy on the orc strong hold helped connect why and where this second orc army came from. Her grief over Killi also helped add to the heartbreak. 

My ONLY issue is that their was no mourning scene over Fili like there was for his brother and uncle. Fili deserved more tears haha

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
To all people who think the Hobbit is the last time you will see Middle Earth on the big screen just remember the English copyright laws state that 70 years (Under the 1995 regulations) after the death of the author the material is free to use. The debate will be if JRR is the true author of the Silmarillion/Lost Tales (The only real way to make more Movies/TV shows). JRR may have written the material but his son Christopher finished and published both works so its up for debate who actually "wrote it". So lets do some math.

If JRR Wrote it:
Died in 1973 so its 27 years to 2000
2000+43( The remaining # of years) = The year 2043 (Best Case Scenario)

If Christopher Wrote it:
Still alive but 90 years old (lets assume he will die within 5 years, kind of rude I know)
2015,2020 +70 = Between the years of 2085 and 2090 (Worse Case Scenario)

I'm not a legal expert so i'm sure this will be debated endlessly in courts.


But in the end money talks so i'm sure we will be seeing one much sooner
after all in the words of JK Rowling¬†

‚ÄúThere's always room for a story that can transport people to another place.‚Äù

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
The latest and the last of the three part series of The Hobbit: The Battle Of The Five Armies. I was very disappointed in the first two, which were a real let down compared to the LOR series. This latest is a totally different animal. I'm not sure if directer Peter Jackson took some of the criticisms to heart from the last two movies and made it right, or he'd always planned the last one to make up for the first two, but it does. For lovers of the LOR series (and you'd have to screwed in the brain not to be a fan of those movies frankly...) this latest movie is much closer to them.

The first two Hobbit movies felt directed at kids, suffered CGI overkill, and just left most serous LOR fans flat. This latest movie is much more adult oriented, CGI used to enhance vs dominate as it did for LOR, solid acting, great battle scenes, and Action from start to finish. It does not have the "magic" of LOR, but it's a solid A- movie that almost makes up for those last two duds.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
Say what you want about Peter Jackson, but his movies got me into all of the Tolkien books. When i was a kid, i saw LOTR for the first time in theaters and was amazed, which prompted me to read the LOTR book which is one of my favorite books. Then when the hobbit came out a few years ago, that made me read the Hobbit which i absolutely loved. From there i've also read much more of Tolkien's work such as the Silmarillion for example.

I understand Jackson added some extra characters that were not in the book (tauriel, pale orc, legolas, etc). But lets face it guys, this is hollywood, they need a love story (tauriel and kili), an antagonist (pale orc), and one of the most beloved characters from LOTR to get fans' attention (legolas).

Say what you want about the movies, i thought they were phenomenal and were definitely worth the money i spent on a movie ticket. Of course i prefer the books, but the movies help me get a better picture in my head of what the landscape/characters look like which helps me in reading the books. And everyone is mad about the CGI orcs in this film, but i think the orcs look so much more badass than in LOTR where it was just guys with terrible makeup jobs. Just my personal opinion, but i love both series. Not to mention that i can't get enough of Gandalf!!!

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment: How can there be so much ignorance about this trilogy? First of all, if you have a complaint, make it a valid one, not like "wow, such a short book made into such long movies!" If you didn't know, art makes it possible to stretch one single page of writing to a whole series... but that involves creativity and many other things you're not exactly aware (or capable) of. Secondly, using insults and dirty words all over means you are still around 14 and have no superior reasoning capacities, have a very poor self esteem and many psychological issues. Fact! Also, it's beyond pathetic to give so much time of your life to hating something you don't like. Just get over it! Judging by something so simple as the likes and dislikes bar here, by the web activity of fans, by the hype around the premieres and all events and, ultimately, by the numbers of sold tickets and DVS's, Hobbit haters are definitely a very tiny minority. You don't like this film? Fine! You are perfectly entitled to that... but you can only come across as ridiculous with your silly complaints. No, they didn't 'butcher' Tolkien's work. If you want to call it like that, every movie adaptation does that. That's why it's an 'adaptation'. That's why it's 'based on' a book. You're only showing you have no idea about how art is made, especially how they make the transition from book to film. No, Tolkien isn't rolling in the grave, because he was smart enough to be aware of all the possibilities when he agreed to give away the rights. Also, you're no necromancer to know what he's doing beyond the grave, nor did you meet him while he was alive. And then, Christopher is a bad argument here, because he's a bitter old man looking for massive earnings and biting the hand that feeds. Last but not least, trolls shouldn't bother commenting on this because I don't follow youtube threads. Grow up.

Comment: I really loved the Hobbit trilogy! In my opinion, the movie wouldn't be so deep and entertaining if it was exactly like the book. They did an amazing job to expand the characters' personalities. Character development in the book is almost non-existent and the action isn't great either. If you wanted it to be like the book then you would have EVERYTHING from Bilbo's perspective (so it would be quite one-dimensional) and you wouldn't have scenes like Thorin's touching death scene or the battle at Dol Guldur. Yeah, a few parts were campy but it was never meant to be epic like LOTR.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
I would like to thank mr. J.R.R. Tolkien for this magnificent fairy tale world he was inspired with and gave to us, in book form it was much worth for sure.
I would also like to thank Peter Jackson who achieved, with his amazing, spectacular work, corrections and CANON add-ons on these movies, to have me be entranced, captivated throughout the full length of all three films.
The third movie was the most epic part of this masterpiece, for it included joy, wits, friendship, partnership, romance, sorrow, the soul's strength (for Thorin, who managed to defeat his greed, compared to old Thror) and great amusement in general.

The actors, the costume designs, the make-up, the CGI effects, were all remarkable, majestic.
I believe every person has his own opinion on anything.
We can not have common tastes after all.
Just stop arguing and blaming Mr. Jackson, a person who put so much effort in bringing the Universe of the Hobbit in life, like he did with LOTR, in filming those gigantic blockbusters. And my opinion is, he did great.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment: I can appreciate the three Hobbit movies (and LOTR movies, since they took a few liberties of their own) as their own thing. They don't follow the timeline 100% and they stray from the original path, adding characters/storylines, etc, etc. And that's fine with me. As a fan of both the books and the lore of Middle-earth, I am fine with it being different. So long as the movies were enjoyable (and they were, for the most part), I am perfectly fine with it. And if Tolkien were still with us, I'm sure he'd be okay with it, too.

Comment: I just watched this and I'm here to tell you that it sucks. Tolkien is rolling in his grave at this abomination. I only hope in 10 yrs or so someone tries it again. Different director/writer that can actually stick to the story. The Hobbit is full of wonderful adventure without the need of poorly written romance and terribly conceived characters. I could go on and on about how dissatisfied I was with this whole "trilogy" but I won't. I only say to those who actually know Tolkien's tales and have not viewed this, you have been warned.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment: This is a pretty impressive trailer. Seeing it for the first time, and I watched the movie on Xmas day. Unfortunately, it was a pretty huge let down. ¬†Overly long sub plots that lead nowhere, inconsistent characterization, and distractingly bad continuity. By my count, the ragtag army of humans seemed to have more people at the end of the film than it did at the beginning, and this was after taking heaving losses from the battles. I'm exaggerating a bit, but seriously, this movie played like it was for children. Having grown up on the original LOTR Trilogy, I had very high hopes for these films ... just disappointing. Some bright spots here and there, but overall, a massive step back from the original.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
I'm so tired of people saying how bad Peter messed up the Hobbit films etc. I just read the book. I think it's a very good read if you want to enjoy Middle-Earth again like me. But it is mainly for children. Some characters didn't even have personalities, for ex. the dwarves. Only Thorin but he was also pretty shallow. Some scenes were so short (like their visit to Elrond in the first part) that to put that in a film would be ridiculous. Bringing back Azog is also not a bad idea. Bringing in Sauron (since there is a mention in the book that Gandalf took care of him) it is not a bad idea. Bringing in Tauriel is not a bad idea since there were no female characters in the story. And it is also interesting that Peter basically switched Bard's and Thranduil's behaviour towards the dwarves. In the book Thranduil didn't rush the war. Bard was the more hostile one.
But my only problem with this third part is the ending. SPOILER:
I think Peter should have shortened the fight scenes and given a proper burial to all the dwarves that had fallen. And also a scene where Dain (like in the book) gives everyone their share of the treasure. Even to Thranduil. I would have enjoyed it very much...Oh and maybe Beorn should have had a bigger role in the battle. Since in the book he killed Bolg.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
I know there are those out there that stake their claim as either fans of the movie or fans of the book, but as a true student of Tolkeins works, having been introduced to their literary mastery at a young age... I found the movies to be quite faithful to the book and vastly successful at bringing the world of Tolkein to life. 
Tolkein was very strict with his creations and when he sold them, those who obtained them were at first terrified to even approach them. Even Peter Jackson was lost at how to begin tackling the tremendous task of bringing a book to life on the big screen. And while, yes, it does contradict some things in the book, I will go right ahead and defy everyone now who is going to condemn me for saying this.

Tolkein would be proud. 

It is hard to speak for a dead man, and even harder to say that I enjoyed the books more than the movie, and was amazed at its imagery and the faithful representations of the characters from the book. Sure some things were off... The size of Durin's Bane, a little comedy sprinkled onto the trolls, etc. and the tiny risks taken with a vast majority of them being hits.

Tolkein knew that there were few who could truly appreciate his work, and I have to say that Jackson is one of the true appreciations for its majesty. 

For those of you who hate the movies and spit on any adaption that is not an original Tolkein work, that is fine. But respect those who love Tolkein for another reason, and thank those who read the books after seeing the movies. Thank those who shed tears for Boromir and feared Frodo's death. Thank those who laughed at the lighthearted movie Gollum and the extra scenes created by the hand of the original writer as well as Jackson himself. 
We all seem to forget from time to time that no one is Tolkein himself, but there are others besides ourselves who share our deep love of Middle-Earth and all it's people...

When we learn to accept that... I believe we will be better for it, and be one step closer to understanding the true genius of Tolkeins creations, and those clever and brave enough to take up the pen he left for them.

Middle-Earth will never be forgotten... And it will be us to carry on its legend to our children, and our children's children. Our adventures with the Hobbits of Bag-End on their great journeys through the kingdoms of elves, dwarves, and men alike.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment: I finally saw the film, (spoilers here, so if you have not seen the film then read on at your own risk!) I would say Peter entertained me 68.5% of the time, saw the 3D version, which also added a touch of wonder here and there but was not used to full impact. There were sections that followed closely with the movie that were well done, sections that were made up that were OK and areas that could have been better. I did particularly enjoy the Dol Guldur sequence with the White Council battling Sauron and the Nazgul (taken from the LOTR ROTK appendices).¬† I personally did not like the way Thranduil was portrayed in this one, he still came off as pompous and self centered, although he did attack the mountain with his army in the books, his intentions and his personality were noble in nature, maybe a bit more rustic compared to Elrond, but admirable. I also felt like the battle scene toward the end of the film did not seem to show the Eagles, Elves, Dwarves and Men winning the fight in any sort of detail, it switched focus to the private battles between Azog, Bolg and the Dwarves, (and Tauriel) and when all the 1:1 conflicts were over the big battle seemed to have ended too. I also was hoping to see more Eagles and Beorn in bear form fighting, I suppose those things will be included on the extended version DVD which I am sure will come out around May 2015. Overall we have begun to take Mr. Jackson for granted, and hardcore Tolkien fans are not going to like many of the liberties he and his writers have taken with the plot, this once again is a film interpretation and is aimed at entertaining both fans of the book and those who have never read them, any director who would take on Tolkien's spectacular mythos and is 68% successful has to be commended, if he changed his mind in 5 years and recreated the Silmarillion in some form I would still shell out $15 or so to see it. Even if it was filled with CGI Balrogs, Dragons and Orcs!

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
SPOILERS!!



I guess we all just caught small glimpses of either deleted scenes or scenes that will be added to the Extended versions.¬†

I watched the movie today expecting to see a few specific things that this trailer showed, but I didn't see them.

1) In the trailer, we see the Elves fire a volley of arrows at, what I can only guess is the Dwarves, as they fire in the exact direction that we see the Dwarves arrive from in the actual movie.

2) In the trailer, we also see a split second scene of Dwarves firing some ballista looking things. Again, not seen in the movie.

3) Lastly, I don't remember any speech from Gandalf in the movie either, yet in this trailer we hear a line that sounds like the end of a motivational speech.
Gandalf - "You have but one question to answer, how shall this day end"...

I'm rather disappointed that they didn't keep these in, more so the first two as I personally love any and all combat scenes.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
It was cool. I noticed many conveniences like in the other films. There are film rating guide lines and regulations that I know filmmakers must follow in order to keep the rating they desire upheld to their film and that lead me to believe that was why only Orcs were be headed and not humans which seemed dark but the humans weren't which took me out of it a bit. Whenever a human or "light" character would be killed they would be saved or some type of "Dues ex Machina" would happen to keep them alive. In relation to that I noticed some scenes had a ton of effort for conveniences. An example would be the hobbit in barrels knocking/defeating all the like 15 Orcs away while staying alive.

There were times where the movie wanted to be dark, then funny, then slap stick and dark again. But only horrific and brutal with chopping heads of the "bad guys" not the protagonist or "heavenly like" character like Legolas.

Legolas is annoying invincible and flawless and still wants to be Fred Flint stone whenever he can. When Woody from 'Toy Story' declared "falling with style" Legolas perfectly fits that phrase. This guy is untouchable to the pint where I want him to loose some and I shouldn't feel that way. He even took Rey Mysterio's wrestling love using his legs to clamp down on an Orcs neck and swing himself across to take the Orc down. I was like that's WWF üòÆüòë lol, I liked it a lil bit. This lead me to enjoy when the Head Orc beat him or "roughed him up some" and made him "bleed his own blood" ha ha haaaaaaaa..... ¬†That's goes with other characters too that unreasonably beat and over powered these strong Orcs with brute physical force with thin brittle arms (That lady Elf who had "the hots" for the one elf who almost "took an arrow to the knee" and had Legolas salty and jelly).

There were some funny moments and I liked some of them. I could see the film was about friendship, trust, journey ¬†and acceptance while conflicting with greed, race war, and power.¬†

I really liked the boss scene at the end which caught me off guard for a bit. It was recalling good.

Overall I could nit-pick the film a lot and point out a ton of minor things that would make sense for the individual characters motives but I liked it. To counter argue the plausibility of characters not doing what would make sense is to keep the suspense going because if they didn't then the story may not be that compelling or thrilling in tense moments, like when the lead hobbit could've slice the head orcs neck when he was behind him as they were looking at the Eagles. It's all for the sake of Storting telling and I keep that in mind as well.

Comment:
I went into this movie having no idea what the plot of Lord of the Rings was.

There were too many names, so I just called them Gandalf, Dildo Baggins, ninja elf, dragon slayer man, albino orc leader, stuck up prince, ginger elf, midget king, and red dragon.

As for the movie itself, it was very... meh. Dildo Baggins and Gandalf are the only characters I came to like. Everything was just drama, explosions, millions of arrows, more explosions, important fight scene that involves the good guy being saved by another good guy, more drama, and then, before I knew what was happening, the movie ended with a boring "returning home" scene.

Seriously though. LOTR needs some comic relief and more interesting characters. Every single character besides Baggins and Gandalf were drama queens.

Comment:
I have watched the movie and in my opinion, it is not a bad movie or a good movie. It is an average movie. The 1 &2 movie followed the book closely (not perfectly) but it is in the 3e that the book and the movie become 2 separate thing.
(SPOILER)
(SPOILER)

(SPOILER)

The battle become the focus of the movie for about 1h45 of the full 2h24 minutes when it was barely 5 pages in the book. Lots of thing were added, some good like the participation of legolas who link the movies, other were just stranges, like the bats and the second army that serve almost no purpose in the movie. The editing was strange, the movie would cut in the middle of an encounter between protagonist to another group of people far away for no apparent reason,etc. The battle last far too long, it is approximately an 1hour long, after 45 minutes of seeing people kill each other and constant rise in stake, it become more tedious than inspiring.
It wasn't bad but some choices made were out of place or not needed.

This is all my opinion, what do you think? Was it a good movie, a bad movie or something in between?

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
A review of the film I did for my forum
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The latest hobbit film is utterly ridiculous! It is rife with ludicrous and deeply embarrassing overacting,¬† laboured pontification, and a torrent of mindless slashing, all delivered in over zealous CGI. The actors declaimed as though on a stage in an auditorium, but perhaps they were desperate to gain the audience's attention because they knew they would be fighting for attention with the CGI action which was made less for being so grandiose and arbitrary. Only a rather charming female elf seemed remotely engaged with the real world and her diary was filled to the brim with casually decapitating orcs, being rescued and sobbing, leaving little time for anything else.

http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/49/EvangelineLillyAsTauriel.jpg/220px-EvangelineLillyAsTauriel.jpg

The film was just downright childish, simplistic and bombastic.

Much of the film was an extended battle scene between "five armies" that was chaotic, confused and meaningless with the highlight being a fashion statement by an elven army that thought it was on parade, a fashion parade. The elves had the shiniest, gaudiest and best polished armour that seemed designed to light up the battlefield and set new standards of Middle Earth couture. The Elves' idea of fighting seemed to be posing and dancing; they pirouetted and pranced about in a staged choreography that they must have practised day and night because never a foot or spear was out of place in a faultlessly synchronised display.

The director, Peter Jackson, appears to be incapable of delivering credible¬† characters or narrative. His characters are simply immature; they were schoolchildren playing at being adults and almost all the actors seem to have been instructed to add dramatic weight to their delivery by constantly shouting or grimacing in a failing struggle for gravitas which made them look silly .

The only redeeming features were the girly elf and the rather charming underlying theme of the virtue of English manners and understatement, exemplified by the diffident character of Bilbo who would interject some of the melodramatic and bombastic declamations by other characters with a timid comment, usually a plea for everyone to get along, calm down and be nice. Oddly, the dragon, despite being a sadistic genocidal creature who delivered the most spine chilling moments and most credibility to a character, managed to bring a touch of decorum to proceedings with his perfect diction and grammar.

The film attempted to depict some human frailty, well dwarven frailty, in the corrosive effect on the mind of power and wealth; judgement and empathy were suggested as immediate victims along with general mental well being, but¬† it failed horribly. The script was hopelessly inept and ponderous as it tackled these themes and struggled to offer anything more than might be expected of an ill-read¬† teenager forced to consider the subject.

The end of the battle was particularly silly. The elves, having put on a fashion show, retired to clean their armour for the next performance, the dwarves were hacked to a standstill by orcs who had a clever plan, apparently, for some of them to retreat just as they were on the verge of victory, when suddenly the battlefield was overtaken by hordes of huge eagles who could transform into killer bears. They came from absolutely nowhere and without any narrative justification whatsoever, but nonetheless they had a firm idea of their role and slashed away at the remaining orcs. A brief shot of a character on a sleigh who had rescued Gandalf in an early part of the film suggested he was controlling the aerial army, but he could have been a birdwatcher for all the narrative sense his appearance made. It was weirdly arbitrary; as though the director had got bored with hours of battle scenes and turned to the last page of the script, leaving all of the intervening storyline unrendered. The remaining orcs were dispensed in a moment and the backup orc army disappeared and suddenly Bilbo and Gandalf waved their goodbyes after some mutual compliments and set some of the narrative elements for Lord of the Rings.

5/10

Oddly, despite it being littered with flaws, ridiculously immature characterisation, and an inept script, I was entertained. It was so bad it was good in some ways and I don't resent having seen it, and of course there was the elven girly and the fabulously cultured dragon.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
Before watching the third movie, I was a big fan of The Hobbit. To begin with, LOTR is my bible and the movies are absolutely the best ever made. There can't be a better movie than LOTR.

The first two Hobbit movies were really enjoyable. Sure there are some flaws only LOTR is flawless after all. Everything was going so well. The tention was building thorought Unexpected journej and Desolation of Smaug. The beginning of Battle of the five armies was also superb. But after they killed the dragon in went downside so fast that it ended in the bottom of the ocean. So much hacking and slashing and no story at all. Elf/dwarf romance was silly as hell. And suddenly the movie became a 3d game. Legolas was deffinately playing God of war, controlling trolls with the joyst.... ahem sword. Flying with bads like Kratos with Harpies, I mean come on. This movie was never supposed to be about how many orks can you kill in ridiculuous ways. It became a parody. I didn't even cared about anyone in the end. I cryed my eyes in LOTR several times in sad scenes like Boromir death, here it all seems lame and like a video game.

Now I fully agree with Cristopher Tolkien that Jackson shouldn't be allowed to ruin Silmarillion and make it a CGI orc slaughter movie. I personally would give such a difficult project to Chris Nolan. You need to bond with the characters and to make a believable action scenes just like in LOTR.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
Would all of the people who would burn the hobbit at the stake because it doesn't follow the book please listen up. 

Peter Jackson has done more than Tolkien had thought of at that time. There was more happening than strictly the events of the hobbit at that time, and many of those events began to roll the stones down the hill which became the LotR trilogy. Tolkien wrote a book called the similarion, which has some stories about the events which happen during the hobbit that aren't expressed in the book, and they explain why Gandalf had to leave so many times for so long. Peter Jackson has actually done more than his job required, and I personally believe that his willingness to tie all of middle earth together should be applauded. 

Except for that stupid dwarf- elf love story. That and legolas(while he was alive at that time) is complete bullshit.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment: Just returned from the theater, It was VERY, VERY good. By far the best of the 3 Hobbit movies. Silent tears were pouring from my eyes and down my face during the last 20 minutes, and of course during the credits when Billy Boyd's "The Last Goodbye" was being played. I know that many critics have had negative things to say about the Hobbit movies being made with so much extra fluff, non existent characters, and too much emphasis on the impending struggle with the One Ring, (they do that here too) but for what it's worth, their are a lot of poignant scenes filled with much emotion on top of the battles that truly get your blood going. Peter Jackson left Middle Earth ALMOST as pristine as when he first got there. Will go again.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
Peter Jackson, I can say without doubt that you majorly fucked up. Before I go into detail about why this film was such a train wreck, let me please explain how Tolkien's life work was not yours to butcher. In Jackson's adaptation of LOTR, you can see how ,despite several book differences, a lot of heart and soul was put in by a crew of people who had clearly read the books. And I can honestly say, despite¬†disagreeing with the decision to make¬†a trilogy,¬†that the first two Hobbit films weren't too bad, quite good even. But moving onto the Battle of Five Armies.
My real pet peeves of the film was the fact that this seemed like a film made for the fans of the films, not the books.¬†The film had a real sense of absence of what Tolkien intended and felt more like fan service for the lovers of 'orc¬†slaying and¬†epic-ness' that¬†had been previously featured in¬†Jackson's take on capturing Middle-Earth.¬†An example of this being a film made for the¬†average movie goer was during a conversation between Legolas and Tauriel where Legolas almost blatantly explains to Tauriel (or the audience as I saw it) what Gundabad is. Now as petty as this seems, I think it sounds incredibly stupid for the son of an Elf prince to explain to a warrior elf what the main fortress of their ancient enemy is. Another annoyance was the constant unnecessary switching between Sindarin and Westeron between the two, it made no sense what so ever, as if a Frenchmen began talking to another Frenchman in French but then to randomly begin speaking English to each other. I also absolutely despised Tauriel and Alfrid, lets begin with Alfrid. Alfrid was a clear reprint of Grima Wormtongue with the exception of over the top villainy and childish humour (also from the Master of Laketown). Tauriel on the other hand was only included to be 'the Hobbit's¬†Eowyn', an annoyingly bland heroine. I disliked her most in this film for the reason to add a clich√©d origins story in the plot, so that the viewer might care for her and that it could be reintroduced further into the story.
There was also how lazy and¬†Hollywood-ised¬†this¬†film felt, even some of the acting was bad. Thorin's scene when he threatens Bilbo in the armaments of Erebor was quite frankly hilarious, and Martin Freemans¬†acting felt¬†sloppy,¬†as if¬†Freeman was playing Freeman instead of Bilbo. This is probably due to the¬†absence of Bilbo, don't get me wrong, he had more screen time than Beorn (who¬†was given¬†a mere five seconds just to satisfy viewers like me) but characters like Thranduil had way too much screen time. I¬†was expecting¬†Jackson to make up for this in the ending...which after forty five minutes of introducing all of the cast¬†in the first film¬†gave me an incredible lack of satisfaction. To expect after a thirteen month long journey, he was just going to 'slip away queitly', we don't even learn what happened to Bard, or Dain, or the remaining ten dwarves for that matter, I mean you could always look them up after but it would have been better if they had paced better. Overall,¬†The Hobbit:¬†The Battle of Five Armies¬†has proven to be a lazy, boring, funny for the wrong reasons, extremely clich√©d and a CGI overkill of a movie!

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
Went and saw it last night, I¬†don't care what anybody says, I thought it was amazing.¬† I grew up loving the Hobbit and¬†LOTR books because my father read them to me as a child.¬† I'm not 23 and last night for me was the culmination of my childhood and it seemed that way for everyone in the audience, I sat front and center and heard gasps, laughing, and crying from behind me.¬† As the credits began to roll their were thunderous applause and then they quickly died down as Billy Boyd started to sing the last goodbye.¬† I sat there in silence with my eyes closed listening, thinking about how much these 2 trilogies have, and always will mean to me.¬† Once the song was over, I stood up and began to walk out of the theatre noticing that everyone was also still sitting, some people wiping tears from their eyes.¬† These books and movies mean a lot to people, not in a Harry Potter, Star Wars kind of way, but in their own way entirely.¬† The books transcend literature and are among the best selling books of all time, and the movies, though changed from the books, I feel do them justice.


Thank You JRR and Peter for what you've done, job well done.


‚ÄúFaithless is he that says farewell when the road darkens.‚Äù - Gimli, The Fellowship of The Ring

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
The Hobbit trilogy for me is one of the best examples of movie makers becoming lazy. In the LOTR trilogy, each film costed approximately $100 million each and Peter Jackson scoutted out some of the most beautiful locations in New Zeland to film, had every single piece of armor worn by the orcs customed made, and used trick shooting to make the appearance of Gandolf seem much larger than the Hobbits. In the Hobbit, each film costed approximately $300 million each and they flew all the way to New Zeland to film the entire movie in their most beautiful WAREHOUSE with green screens, made all the orcs CGI and just used CGI to make the hobbits appear smaller. The making of The Hobbit actually brought Sir Ian Mckellen to tears while filming because shooting in an entirely green environment felt so cheap to such a classic actor and he considered it shameful compared to all the effort put into the LOTR films.

Comment:
If this is but the final combat pulse, evolution¬†of a long, convoluted, strategy, why is Sauron committing to a fight which can only bring a massed opponent about, as allies, to fight the ONE threat which they all recognize is greater than their petty bickering?

Sauron would wait until after the battle, when all the combatants, win or lose, were on their knees, bleeding from savage attrition, to wipe them out, in detail.

Sun Tzu:

1.¬† Choose the ground, 25%
2.¬† Know thy limits, 25%
3.¬† Know thy enemy's weaknesses, 25%
4.¬† Win without taking the field, 100%.

AT BEST, you can only get a 75% win condition from combining all the available factors leading up to a battle.¬† But if you let your enemy slaughter themselves unto near corpse like pallor, then you can defeat in detail the remainder at 100% certainty of victory and zero risk of loss.

Bleed for time, bleed for lives, bleed for victory.¬† But _never bleed for dirt_.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
Just saw the movie.... Projector in our theater broke, so we waited for one hour extra for it to begin. ¬†We each received a free movie voucher as a reward for waiting. ¬†5 minutes in, the projector breaks again... ¬†So here we are debating whether we leave or go. ¬†But we're in for the long haul. ¬†We're freaking Lord of the Rings fans, right? ¬†Once it is finally resolved, the movie begins, but none of us have faith in it to make it all the way. ¬†What happens next is legendary [SPOILER ALERT]

SPOILER:







About the time where Azog is killing Fili, the lights come on in the theater, and the sound cuts off. ¬†Soon, the stupid First Look advertisements start playing overtop the movie, with all this techno music and whatnot. ¬†Soon after, Fili is getting stabbed in the back to this hilarious assortment of techno music that fits both the expressions and cartoon-like actions of the characters as they run to avenge their fallen friend. ¬†I have never laughed harder in my entire life. ¬†I have it on video, but it would be near impossible for me to share it without it being removed immediately. ¬†I also was laughing too hard to keep the camera steady, and the music is only faintly heard. ¬†I will NEVER forget this. ¬† The movie wasn't very good, but that one moment made it all worth it.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
why is so many people afraid, or threatened, or raging about this? Are you afraid that the ones who didn't read the books are going to have a missconception of it? Are you afraid that the books themselves are gonna be ruined by a movie? I promise that when i go and watch the movie, i'll put my LOTR, Silmarillion and The Hobbit books in a safe-deposit box, so they can't get "ruined" in the process.
¬†I know they want to make good profit of a not so long book (because they can't make ¬†movies of everything that they didn't show in the LOTR trilogy), a book that was innocent and fast to read, which was a great fun adventure. Now it became super epic, full of darkness, and not so following the book, and it doesn't feel like it felt when reading the book. But at least this are (very) good quality movies that can actually take you there in that world, make you a part of it, where nothing seems like a plastic full of cgi scenery (i know that in this regard LOTR trilogy was so much carefull). And they can show you a part of the story that they couldn't tell in LOTR, because it was one movie per book, but they are showing it here.
¬†To me these movies doesn't have the same amount of time or love (i don't know how to call it) than the LOTR trilogy. But i don't have any concern about them changing facts about the books, and making "The Hobbit" a whole different experience than the book gave. I loved both movies, and i guess i'll love this too. I know i shouldn't be expecting The Hobbit experience, but some long epic battles full of heroes, and some facts about other books, and i think it won't dissappoint me. I really can't wait to watch this.
PD: I'm just glad they showed Radagast the brown, that is enough for me.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment: Let me just present an opinion of mine regarding the controversy around the Hobbit and The Lord Of The Rings. The lord of the rings movies are almost universally preferred over the Hobbit and that is an opinion of mine also, I love the Lord Of The Rings movies because of their gritty and realistic feel whereas the Hobbit has a really bright and goofy feel to it. It's almost as if the LOTR films are centred around the politics of it all rather than the actual adventure. But I also love The Hobbit movies, all three. I just recently saw this one and I now feel like I have the right to share my thoughts. Let me start from the beginning, Frodo in the Lord Of The Rings sets out on his journey for a number of reason, one of which being that he has grown up most of his life with his uncle Bilbo and I have no doubt that throughout the years he has heard Bilbo's stories of his wonderful adventures with Magic and Dragons countless times. So when Frodo sets out on his journey, he has an expectation (which I believe he talks about) of a wonderful goofy, magical adventure with dwarves and goblins and treasure but is swiftly cut down to reality when he treks through middle earth and watches his friends get captured, killed and twisted by the power of this inexplicable evil that he must bare. That is the roots of the story. So for Frodo to have this realisation that life is not like the stories he has so often heard, there have to be stories to match this expectation. If the Hobbit was so dark and gritty, it would not only feel weird, it would actually take away from the thrill of the Lord Of The Rings (for me personally at least). There would be no reason for Frodo to expect a simple adventure and there would be no shock value for the audience of comparing the two tones of the each trilogy. So I think the fact that from start to finish, the hobbit looked like an (awesome) video game is exactly what those movies needed. I think Peter Jackson made these movies what they should've¬†been, it just comes down to whether or not you like that. I do not feel that it is a comment on Peter Jackson's direction. After all, I don't think anyone has a problem with the action in any of the movies. I would be shocked if they did. He gives a masterclass in directing action. Just one man's opinion.¬†

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment: Decent movie. Which is bad, because a "Hobbit" movie should not be just decent, it should be atleast 9/10 which this movie is not even close to. I am really dissapointed by this movie actually. There were so many cliffhangers that the film just got boring. It was also super-predictable, you knew every time what would happen. Also hate the fact how the dragon died. They made the dragon so epic and built his "epicness" up in two movies, just to end it like this. It feels like Peter Jackson just wanted to get him out of the way and so he just killed him in the prelog. Sure, the death could have been good if they just would have made the dragon just a "dragon" without personality and shown that he was just a "object" who was not really important. ¬†But the picture I got of him in the two first movies was not that one. He deserved a better death and I feel like they could have made something more with him. And when you really think about what happend in the movie in almost 3 HOURS, it was pretty much only a battle at the same location all the movie. 3 hours without any kind of emotion, just fast cuts and weird fighting scenes. Then in the end they just made the "feels-train" kick in and killed pretty much every important character which made the ending awful imo. And wtf was up with Azogs closest "orc-friend"? He sucked at fighting in the second movie and got his ass kicked by legolas and had to escape. But in this movie he whopped ass like never before, dosent make any sense. This movie was not good and stop pretending it was. The CGI was also really bad at some few scenes in the movie, not cool. Same goes with the music, the music has always been really good in the LOTR films but in this movie the music felt like it did not play any important part and had no impact on the film (The other hobbit films used the music alot better.) Imo Peter Jackson can do alot better and the people who actually say good things about this movie, I think should "rethink" abit and actually try to accept the fact that this movie was not that great, even tho I really dont want to believe it myself. A bad ending for such a cool trilogy. I am not a hater, but after these 16 years, I expected something much much better.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
Hello everyone! I'm from Russia, so please forgive my bad english. I'm here, I want to say: we have started to show this film on December 11 and I had to go on it. Without spoilers!

To say that it was just great - to say nothing, because I would have given Peter Jackson Award for the Smaug's attack on the Lake Town and powerful ending. And for the film as a whole.

Yes, there are drawbacks, such as a suspicious story focusing on unimportant personalities, definitely some strange scenes and inappropriate humor. The battle itself could be a little more ambitious, though, and so very cool.

Nevertheless, despite all the bad places, the film does not disappoint. Entry is so good that I shed a few tears from what I saw familiar faces and the coolest dragon in the history of cinema at its most violent state.

The film itself (by the way, it will be shorter the previous parts) stumbles here and there, but still kept confident. Well, that Comrade Jackson master of battle scenes - could be observed in the other books of the trilogy by Tolkien. The ending is simple and good.

A little sad that such a great director says goodbye to the world of Middle-earth. If you love fantasy, dragons, battles, intrigues, read the book "The Hobbit" and she fascinated you - feel free to go. You will not regret. I would have went. 10 times.

Thank you for "The Hobbit", Peter and everyone else who had a hand in its creation, as well as excellent translators and voice actor trilogy of films in Russian. The song in the credits mesmerizing.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
For everyone thinking about going to the movie, think twice. I can't submit a review on metacritic for the "movie is yet to bee released". But what you see in the trailer/ teaser is not what you get from the movie - Of course you get all the parts as seen but under different circumstances. The trailer does make a good impression and the majority lies on drastic character moments.
Be not mistaken. The movie sadly became too CGI infested and parts in too many ways from the original (book) to be fully enjoyed - especially the second half. The battle is just a pain to watch because there's no depth (it can't be described otherwise, you just feel like it's second nature and nice to look at but misses real threat). Further the love stories and drama are over the top. Maybe it's just my opinion but the majority of spectators in the cinema I was were laughing all over those scenes, cause they were so over-exaggerated. I don't say all is bad but the second half of the movie is - overall - hard to watch (and I don't mean all 100% of the second half) cause it's unreal und unbelievable (Yes, I'm aware it's a fantasy movie but why does everything has to be so pumped up??).
Maybe those who are going to watch the movie anyway will think of my opinion as unreliable - which is your right, as I'm subjective - and others will like the movie in the end for what it is. I'm simply saying it is not what it could be (which means not a dream-version where everything is perfect, but a good narrative as well as execution similar to the quality of LotR) and I really miss that the bad parts (CGI, not true to story, exaggeration, drama & love story, character behavior) ruin something that could have been great in the end.

Watch a movie for entertainment not to see if it follows a book. The only movie that I can say with honesty that was better than the book was Jaws. The movie certainly did not follow the book.

One reads books to be challenged mentally or to place yourself in a similar situation as a person. Movies do not make one think as much, if at all.

The Count of Monte Cristo, there is a scene in books where he is in the bag as he is to be thrown down into the sea, how does one handle that part in a movie?

For that matter I have yet to see a movie that comes close to what Dune accomplishes.

Comment: I am a huge fan of Tolkein's work, and I know this stuff pretty well (Although I recognize there are many more who know a lot more), but I am not angry at Peter Jackson messing up some (Ok, a lot of) things in these movies. You need to understand, that a movie shouldn't do exactly what the base material did. That is BORING! A retelling in movie format is just stupid. Why would ANYONE ever want to see that. You watch movies BASED on books (NOTICE THE BASED) so you can see a different interpretation that what you read. It doesn't really matter Jackson changed things in the universe, for it the movies' universe is different from Tolkein's. You need to look at the movies as almost as something separate from the material is based on. This is how I find myself enjoying these movies. It's simply no fun to rage at something like this.

Comment: I love middle earth, im not going to use a hyperbole or go over the top. there is hardly anything that can make me more happy then reading about middle earth, with that out of the way: In the first movie, with the dwarves in Bilbos house (first like 40 mins or so) i enjoyed every second of, it had the least in inaccuracies and i appreciated the minor details (though the changed song, as some one who learnt the original, made me sad) but as it went on and went on it strayed more from the path. this, im not happy with. how i would like it: no tauriel, no legolas, no sauron. is that too much to ask?!?! and while where at it lets not pretend like the CGI made for a good movie, every thing felt bouncy and like actions didnt have consequences. in the lotr, lets say frodo where to be thrown down, he would feel it, the audience would feel it. but when the weird structure feel down the chasm in the misty mountains and it just slid against all odds and no one died, it felt wrong, and just plain boring

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
Spoilers spoilers spoilers coming.










Mixed feelings after leaving the theater. I'm not happy, how the story was changed. Tauriel/Kili took too much time and was dragging even more, nothing but a glimpse of Beorn, I felt like Fili was left out a bit and his death of lame and quick and then he was just forgotten, Fili and Kili should've gone to defend Thorin from Azog and die together. You stole that scene from me. Though it's hard to choose, probably my favourite scenes were the Dol Guldur battle, Bilbo and Gandalf sitting silently Thorin's madness and when he remembers who he really is, Thorin's death: Freeman and Ermitage portrayed that beautifully and it was really sad. Makes me even more sad and somewhat empty, that this journey is over and this was possibly the last Middle-Earth film. I will go see it again, despite it's flaws and start waiting for the trilogy boxset.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
I've been a huge fan of Tolkien for most of my life.¬† I'd read the Hobbit by the age of 9 and the LOTR by the age of 12.¬† I've since read each of them several times over, as well as the lesser read works, such as the Silmarillion, Unfinished Tales etc.¬† I've even read things like 'Farmer Giles of Ham', 'Tree & Leaf' and Sir Gawain and the Green Knight'.

The relevance of all this ^ ?¬† I'm still looking forward to this film enormously!¬† :)

Too many people are moaning about discrepencies between the book and the films.¬† The same accusations could be levelled at the LOTR films, which I also loved.¬† I accepted the fact that journeys were truncated, that Tom Bombadil and Goldberry were left out, that Glorfindel was replaced by Arwen and the whole Aragorn/Arwen love story padded out.¬† I could understand the cinematic reasons for such choices.¬† I even overlooked more serious deviations.¬† Such as Saruman working directly for Sauron, instead of for himself... or the complete omission of the 'Scouring of the Shire'.¬† The latter, for me, being one of the most important chapters in the book.¬† It's omission was the only serious complaint I had with the films.¬† I let it go though, as overall he had captured the feel of the books so well and the main story remained largely unchanged.

So we come to the Hobbit.¬† A slim book, written for children.¬† Albeit one that is also enjoyed by adults.¬† He could have made a children's film, interspersed with references for adults but I doubt that would have gone down well.¬† Especially since the expectations following his LOTR films were so high.¬† Instead he chose to go in a similar vein.¬† Obviously it would require more padding but... and it's a crucial 'but'... virtually all of the extra story is either implied and extrapolated from the Hobbit itself, or sourced from Tolkien's other books set in, or about, Middle Earth.¬† The main narrative storyline remains unbroken and all of the major events in the book also occur in the film.¬† He's stated, quite clearly, that this wasn't a straightforward re-telling of the Hobbit alone, that he wanted to widen the scope to include other elements of Middle Earth that were contemporary and to expand on some sections of the Hobbit that were interesting but for which there was little detail.¬† I think he's done this pretty successfully.¬† Yes there are elements added that don't occur anywhere in Tolkiens writings but they aid the plot and the narrative drive.¬† The timeline of a couple of events maybe slightly out too.¬† None of these detract from the film, nor do they feel as if they are things that don't belong in Middle Earth.¬† Even the slight anachronisms don't feel particularly anachronistic, in the context of the film.

You are already suspending your disbelief, re' magic, elves, dwarves, hobbits, orcs... the whole of Middle Earth in fact.¬† Just relax, suspend it a tad more and enjoy the films for what they are,¬† Great storytelling, the mould of Tolkien, set in Tolkiens world.¬† No the are not an exact representation of the book, 'the Hobbit'.¬† They aren't meant to be and they never could be.¬† If it annoys you so much, that they aren't an exact re-telling, that new characters have been added, parts expanded on and other (generally consistent) bits added... then don't go and see the films.¬† For those that are able to overcome their 'rage' at such things, sit back and enjoy the show!¬† ;)

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment: Yes, The Hobbit is a cash grab.  Perhaps the CGI is too heavy.  Maybe it didn't exactly follow the book to the letter.  And yes, maybe the 48 fps was a different  experience that some didn't like.  But throughout each of these films, I found myself loving every second of it.  People keep complaining that this film didn't live up to LOTR, yet they forget that the Hobbit story was written by Tolkien as a fun adventure instead of the detailed epic that Lord of the Rings was.  In retrospect, The Lord of the Rings (book or film) is one large story split into three parts.  Its my favorite film franchise and book series ever, so I was very interested to see what Jackson would do with this new trilogy.  With the first two installments, I had a blast.  The action (particularly in the Goblin-town tunnels in An Unexpected Journey and the barrel riding scene in The Desolation of Smaug) were very well-done and entertaining.  The characters were likable and interesting, with Freeman's Bilbo being the best version of the character yet and Armitage's Thorin Oakenshield being a fantastic addition.  I could feel the emotion that made the Lord of the Rings such an epic experience, with Bilbo's speech about home & the dwarves walking through the caves of their lost home being truly moving scenes.  Benedict Cumberbatch's portrayal of Smaug was a revelation.  The actor not only brought the mighty dragon to the big screen, he truly gave us the most memorable dragon ever in cinema.  I'd argue he has been the most charismatic and interesting villain in the entire franchise, including Lord of the Rings.  The Riddles in the Dark scene between Gollum and Bilbo was absolutely brilliant, actually making me laugh and feel the tension throughout.  Andy Serkis will always be captivating as Gollum, who will soon become one of the most fleshed out characters of the franchise.  So was the Hobbit a cash grab?  Yes, but I don't see all these complaints about The Hunger Games or Harry Potter's final installments being turned into two parts.  While I really loved both parts of Mockingjay and the Deathly Hallows, they never fully sold me on them being made into two films.  But whether or not the Hobbit should've been split into a trilogy, to me they have justified their existence by each being a memorable and epic experience.  And when people complain how it doesn't follow the book, they seem to forget the Lord of the Rings trilogy really didn't follow the books much either.  Jackson made a lot of changes to the source material, and the results were fine with me.  Legolas wasn't in the book, yet Bloom was a welcome return who was great in each scene.  Radagast the Brown was a little strange at first, but he was certainly a fun character who shouldn't even be compared to the horror that is Jar Jar Binks.  He isn't George Lucas, who created a prequel trilogy based on action figures and merchandise.  Jackson instead has crafted a very entertaining and exciting trilogy that I felt has justified being created.  I would agree some of the CGI could've been toned down a bit, i.e. the Orcs not having the same impact being CGI beasts instead of real actors.  Makes it lose a bit of the grit, but doesn't ruin the experience and I truly still felt that I was in the same Middle-Earth that I fell in love with 13 years ago.  The Hobbit was never meant to surpass Lord of the Rings, but when its all finished in a few weeks we will have the best saga of films ever made.  I will watch all six Middle-Earth films with a smile on my face, loving every second of it.  While The Hobbit may have been a cash grab, most films in Hollywood nowadays still haven't come close to the incredible impact that these films have on people including myself.  I realize most people enjoy these films, but I just wanted to address people complaints about its comparison to Lord of the Rings.  So thank you Peter Jackson, for once again giving me an unforgettable experience.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
In my opinion, I don't think the Hobbit is going to be good. The 3 movies are supposedly based on the book The Hobbit? They are literally just making stuff up as they go along, for those who are too lazy to read, there was no Pale Orc or, or Legolas, not even a love story between Kili and whatever that Elf Girls name is... And the Lord of the Rings References? Constantly talking about Sauron and crap... This is the Hobbit... The Story of Bilbo Baggins and his adventure with Gandalf and the Dwarves, not just a sequel to the Lord of The Rings (Don't argue, it's pretty much what it has turned into..). The Hobbit is supposed to be it's own adventure, it's own (ONE) movie would've cut the cake, but Peter had to go and Pretty Much Rip Apart everything the Lord of the Rings was good for... Don't get me wrong, the Lord of the Rings added and left out quite a bit from the original trilogy, but they did it right... They didn't make a whole movie toward a battle that only lasted two chapters in the book... (Yes, the Battle of the Five Armies only lasted about 2 chapters, for those who do not read)...
Rant Over, Hate or Agree with me.

Comment:
Some people complaining about:

"LotR was 3 books, so 3 movies, ok. But The Hobbit is only 1 book and 3 movies FUCK THIS"

Well, if you read the LotR books, you know that the movies took away 80% of the books. Peter Jackson could easily had made like "Fellowship of the Ring pt 1 and pt 2" and so with TT and RotK.

But he didn't, and made a great adaptation for the movies, even if he took away 80% of the books.

But he is using the whole book of Hobbit to make 3 movies. Yeah, i agree that 3 is a bit much, but 2 movies would be awesome, exploring all the book pages. The problem with The Hobbit 2 is that like...50% of the movie didn't exist in the book.

I don't have problem with this trilogy, Hobbit 1 was great, 2 was good and i bet 3 will be awesome.

Haters gonna hate

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment: I feel like a lot of people were expecting so much from "The Hobbit" films! Let's face it!  "The Hobbit" is more of a blockbuster type film, not an Oscar type film like "The Lord of the Rings" was. That era has passed, if "Lord of the Rings" was made today it would look and feel exactly like "the hobbit" movies! Yeah The Lord of the Rings trilogy is far more superior than The Hobbit Trilogy, but they're still fun and entertaining to watch! And also, I bet we can all agree that these are better prequels than the "Star Wars" ones lol. Even though "The Hobbit" isn't exactly what I hoped It be after watching "The Lord of the Rings" I still enjoy them because of the nostalgia of when I first watched "The Fellowship of the Ring" in theaters back when I was five.The Hobbit is enjoyable, and fun, and I surely can't wait to see The Defining Chapter of this Story-filled Middle-Earth Saga. :)

5. Azog is killed by Thorin but Thorin is badly wounded in return. He‚Äôs saved by Beorn, who gets like 20 seconds on screentime
6. Galadriel confronts Sauron using the power of her ring Nenya
7. Giant worms dig tunnels on the battlefield that allow orcs to swarm everywhere.
8. The Auction of Bilbo‚Äôs goods will be featured.
9. The Master flees from Lake-town in his boat.
10. Rumours of Radagast dying in Dol Goldur aren‚Äôt true. He will live.
11. Bard kills Smaug, but won‚Äôt be using the windlance‚Ä¶ this is destroyed as soon as Smaug attacks. Instead he launches the black arrow using one of the limbs of the bow of the windlance while balancing it on his son‚Äôs shoulders.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment: Reading these comments people are either excited or complaining that Peter Jackson is bullshitting for money. From my super-geek perspective, you are both right! The flashes that were in the Lord of the Rings books are necessary for the transition to make both trilogies be a part of the same story, however, this story could have been done in two movies instead of three. Another thing that really pisses me off is the added side-stories that were not written in the Lord of the Rings or the Hobbit, such as the cross-breed love story. WTF were you thinking?!?!? Either way, this movie cannot be worse than the previous one and should tie together a lot of holes between the Hobbit and the Lord of the Rings!

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment: C'mon people. I know that Jackson took creative galore over The Hobbit saga as opposed to the LoTR trilogy, but does that account for flipping off on a movie bred that answer to many of the fans which still has the LoTR 'craze'? This movie probably won't abide to what the original book is about, but, think about it. Do you really stick to what you're supposed to do? Have you not tried and get out of your miserable, comfy hole? Do you really know what's best in the interest of yourself? Have you ever asked yourself, what if, what's written on the book for this movie translated to the silver screen and what is on said screen for this particular movie went to the book? You would be typing the same exact derogatory remarks about the movie which is not the same from the book, as you are now, you Hobbit detractors. Sure, you never know if you would do so, but, though the CGI is too exaggerated(Take, for example, how the Orcs look from the LoTR trilogy as compared to The Hobbit's Orcs, which is so less terrifying than the LoTR ones), Legolas looks.......... different(What's wrong in keeping his original look, Mr Jackson?), and this probably won't stand up to Return Of The King, it certainly will give what most people want, which is the shock and the "wow" factor, and another story to know from Middle-Earth. Look at how much money the last two installments of The Hobbit made and tell me I'm off my mark. And I'm pretty sure that some of those people who begged for a new installment of Middle-Earth criticized The Hobbit for not being what they felt it should be, and I wonder if they will still be bitching on another Middle-Earth saga release if The Hobbit never sprang up. One of these days, people should learn to at least appreciate what they receive, no matter how rigged it might be. And hey. Have anyone ever thought about voicing out loud "the conditions" on what the next saga would be in the film production crew and the creative staff? Or even the fans?

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
Mkay. All people below complaining about how Peter has butchered the Hobbit - I agree with you. Alright? Wholeheartedly, I do. But please. We've got 3 weeks left until the _last movie ever set in Middle-Earth_ comes out. Can we just enjoy it? You can nitpick and complain all you want later. Peter is trying. He really is. But the problem is today, no one wants story. All anyone wants is cheap action (Micheal Bay, Transformers, I'm looking at you). I know we've witnessed the George Prequel Lucasification of these movies. I realize that. But if you really think about it, Peter's doing the best with what hes got. And I don't think anyone could've done any better.

So lets just finish the ride we got on 13 years ago. If you want to throw up upon departure, washrooms are to your left. But this is it for Middle-Earth for a long, _long_ time.

Comment:
Enough about these movies not following the plot of the book.
Don't get me wrong, I agree that they could have just made one movie since the book is laround 200 pages, and that they shouldn't have added so many things that wasn't in the original book. Concider, however, how boring the movie would be if they followed the plot in detail, since most of the book were just specifying how they travelled around and sang on their journey to Smaug.

As its own story, I still find this to be a great trilogy, but they should have kept it more to the original. The soundtracks, the effects and the plot is great, with the exception of some things that didn't have anything to do with the original storyline.

Comment:
I will see this, of course, but the problem is The Hobbit and The Lord Of The Rings are - admittedly the same author and the same world - *very different stories*.

Fifty First Dates is set in our world, and we see a lovably naff Adam Sandler trying to win over the adorable amnesiac Drew Barrymore.

Then there's Se7en, which is the same world but far, far, far darker.

People should be shown that The Hobbit is, essentially, a bunch of bumbling idiots doing something surprising - and any allusions to the term "EPIC" are illusory.

Comment: @ToFester¬†There were black and other races represented in¬†Laketown. Go back and watch Desolation of Smaug again if you don't remember. The race of men come in all colors in Middle Earth, but the locations where the movies take place is much more north of the territories of men that are darker complected. Even hobbits came in different colors, including the darker Harfoots. Elves are fair complected, and that is that. There were the Moriquendi, or Elves of Darkness, but that was not because of their skin tone. Back in the day before airplanes and globalization, most of our world's darker complected races were more southernly located. This is simply how we as the race of Men evolved. So it is not racist that most of the darker skinned men lived to the south in Middle Earth. It was like that here in our own world for a very long time.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
This looks better than the last two hobbit movies, which isn't a great feat. They are simultaneously over-embellished and lazy. I grew up with the lotr movies, these recent movies do not compare at all favourably. Jackson has truly pulled a George Lucas. 
By any measure from the quality of the colour grading to even the casting (all very poor except for bilbo and characters retained from lotr) these movies have been very disappointing for me. There is no perceptible sense of threat, the villains aren't scary, because they are animated, and action too frequently descends into video game territory and is ludicrously physicsless, I greatly missed the effect of such performers as Lawrence Makoare (Lurtz, Gothmog, Witch-King) that are not adequately replaced by computer magic. I now am regretfully going to turn to some absolute legends, the script by Walsh, Boyens and Jackson is lazy and makes for poorly structured movies as it was never meant to span 3 films (pj milking it for all its worth) filled with empty one liners and stupid gags. Sir Richard Taylor, yes I will go there, some of the design is detached from the possible as the movie makers have gotten carried away. There is a supreme lack of the defining aesthetic of lotr, that it should look like history not like improbable fantasy. Sir Howard Shoare, the scores to lotr are absolute masterpieces. I can't say I remember any of the tunes from these hobbit movies, but I could hum for you now a lot of lotr stuff (even as musically untalented as I am). Andrew Lesnie, who is the absolute genius DP has gone for such fantastical lighting I don't believe the environment, I don't like 48fps it just looks awful. Stephen Fry, I am one of his biggest fans and think he is a fine actor but doesn't fit and feels out of kilter with the Middle Earth of mortensen's Aragorn, hill's Theoden, bean's Boromir and Tyler's Arwen. This is typical of these movies, they don't function on any level as a credible sequel.
Having said all of that, this movie may be saved by that line from Gabdalf at the end of this trailer, all hail the almighty Mackellan.

Comment:
Oh boy...IF YOU DON'T LIKE THE MOVIES, IGNORE THEM!!!! It is so pathetic in eveery hobbit video to see comments like ''WE WANTED THE HOBBIT, NOT THIS'' and stuff. IF YOU WANT THE HOBBIT, READ THE DAMN BOOK! And stop flaming the movies, which always claim to be BASED! BASED on the book, not THE book itself.

THE CHANGES
I, myself, admit that this whole CGI stuff is uncool. But stop claiming that the story is destroyed this way. Yeah, Thror wasn't decapitated, but his neck broke on the impact with Azog, Thrain had already died before Hobbit, and definitely without a Wilhelm scream, Azog had died and his son had taken his place, there was no Tauriel or Goblin King, Legolas didn't appear in the Hobbit book, there was no Arkenstone. SO WHAT? The movies industry always adds extra characters, changes the plot a bit, adds out-of-topic love etc. Just enjoy the movie for what it is, not what it COULD be. Otherwise, just don't watch it. No one obliges you after all, am I right? Chk.

Comment: I see a lot of¬† of people hate on this trilogy but am I the only one who thinks these movies are just good? I mean really good? I don't think Peter is ''murdering'' the books in any way. The actors are really good, the costumes are so badass, the landscapes and the Middle Earth architecture are just spot on, and¬†the story is just amazing (It's an euphemism, God bless Tolkien) Anyway, I think it's not ONLY for money, like Marvel is doing with some of their sequels nowday. It's a really¬†unique franchise. It's a complete fictive world and you won't see another franchise that tries to do the same because it's just impossible. It's not like¬†Divergent, Maze Runners etc that tries to copy Hunger Games. Now THAT's bullshit. Hobbit and LOTR aren't. Anyway. That's just my opinion. Sorry if there's any mistake & nonsenses up there, I don't speak English very well if you know what I mean.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
If I was Peter Jackson. I'd definitely tackle on the challenge of adapting The Silmarillion to film(s). The sheer magnitude and lore of that book, and the most epic battles you'd ever see on screen would be a sight to see. Morgoth Bauglir and the War of Wrath. What about the battle between Melkor and Fingolfin? He wounded Melkors face seven times, eternally gifting him pain for the rest of his life.I also remember there being a huge monster/dragon like creature that would move mountains with a single swing, and create infernos whenever he stepped. He was bigger than any mountain.

Too bad Christopher Tolkien isn't ready to give the rights for the book for a film adaptation, maybe for the better, maybe not. I'd love to see the sheer scale of how the world was created, how dwarves, different types of elves and men were created, and the oncoming battles that ensued.

Comment: People realize that the stuff added into the movies by the writers and Jackson isn't just made up BS .. It's included in the appendix's of The Lord of the Ring books. Granted they have added their twist to it by juicing it up a little (that prolonged Erebor scene with the dwarves and Smaug) but hey it's their last Middle-Earth movie they CAN ever make! They can't make anymore. So hey why not split it into three movies. Why not add more detail and material. Heck there's barely enough story in the Hobbit book for two movies. On the CGI aspect, Jackson wanted the Hobbit movie to be like the book as in he wanted the orcs and goblins to seem kiddish, not scary and mature like in the lotr movies. That's why a lot of it is CGI. Plus New Line sorta forced Jackson to do this. Personally, I love these movies! Film is subjective and everyone has their own opinion. (My opinion is better than yours ;)) )

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
These movies are all about the story(greed, power corruption) and characters which are much more fleshed out than in the book. Also the acting has been wonderful..
Ah, the good old CGI discussion in youtube.. Is that the only thing the CGI whiners are focusing when watching the films?¬†
Already the trailer shows that this movie is gonna be very character oriented..
The main reason to make 3 movies is to connect it better to the LOTR-trilogy. I dont give a shit if movies dont follow the book precisely. And i have read the book. So far this Jacksons approach has been better than the silly childish tone of the book..
Of course these arent nearly perfect films, but there is now "perfect" film in the world. I dont get all the pointless yelling about CGI(Which is best in the business and i watch a lot of movies), nitpicking and "stretching" the story. So far The Hobbit-trilogy has been very entertaining, so i dont care to complain the minor flaws it has.
