Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
Its funny how people complain when movies are old and terrible quality but when technology starts to advance we hate on it just as much. These movies look amazing, who the crap cares how they were made because THEY LOOK EPIC. The world of Middle Earth is supposed to be epic and crazy and I am fed up with people hating on these movies simply because Jackson uses the technology available to him......also who the crap walks into a movie and actually cares about the animation being too good and used too often? The only time I complain about something like that is when the animations are terrible and in this case, they aren't.....in fact, they are stunning.....and also, the fact that people say the trolls and monsters in this movie are completely unrealistic and not believable is literally the dumbest comment ive ever heard....people, they are make believe trolls in a make believe universe filled with make believe characters and you say they aren't realistic?? and frankly I don't understand why Ian McKellen was crying,¬†I mean I know what he was trying to say but when they filmed the Lord of The¬†Rings, as well as the Hobbit movies, they traveled to¬†amazingly beautiful places to film, so the fact that he gets upset with filming¬†alone confuses me.....I mean I feel for him but c'mon dude, you get paid and get to travel to some of the most beautiful places on earth, heck I haven't been outside the USA¬†once and I don't get paid to live in boring¬†ol' Texas¬†but I'm not here crying when I don't get my way....not trying to be inconsiderate cause green screen doesn't sound fun but I am just sick and tired of all the hate that these films get.....

So there is my two cents on the matter (sorry for ranting but I have grown up with the LOTR films and I love every one of them)

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
One thing many of you are missing; Jackson PURPOSELY made this to look like it was indeed made before the LOTR trilogy-looking more like a Video game from 2000 than 2010's far superior special effects, AS TO NOT MAKE THE LOTR TRILOGY LOOK INFERIOR! The addition of new effects were implemented, BUT NOT IN A WAY TO RUIN LOTR! What else should he have done, ruin 3 classics that are his legacy with 3 films stretched out beyond belief from 1 minor book (in comparison) & be accused of trying to remake LOTR???
We BEGGED, he answered, before the grayt Gandalf passes away! He took little to work with, gave his FILM & BOOK fans what we ALL wanted, & kept the 3 classic, all-time great film classics intact!
Afterall, LOTR trilogy will be watched AFTER The Hobbit trilogy in years to come, in chronological order. This way, LOTR will actually look even better than the Hobbits-APPROPRIATELY!

Every1 should be happy enough, all things considered!

Bottom line, Peter Jackson wasn't trying to top any1, himself, ¬†nor anything. He kept it real & as if it were made before LOTR, it's that simple. He had a lot of different types to satisfy, mainly his avid followers who watch ALL of his films, with this fun & risky trilogy. WELL DONE!

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment: I have no idea why people complain about these movies. CGI, find me a fantasy movie that doesn't make use of CGI these days. It's there, it's cheaper to use and it looks good so deal with it. As for the story changes, it's not like PJ Philippa Boynes and Fran Walsh are completely making it up as they go. It's all stuff from tolkiens mind. Also if you tried to adapt a book word for word to a film it'd make for a very boring ass book. I realize Legolas wasn't in the hobbit. But that's just cuz he wasn't mentioned. He's the damn kings son so it's entirely plausible that he'd be present for these events. Things need to be changed and cut out or added from a book for the film to be entertaining. That's what people don't get. Stop trying to look at them as failures for the CGI and changes and start looking at them as an adaptation. It's called an ADAPTATION  for a reason. People need to stop judging so harshly. If not for the fact that they're actually doing a very good job with these films then for the simple fact that's they're just movies. Life will go on if things are different and CGI is used I promise.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
Damn this movie looks really good. A lot better then Desolation of Smaug. I am begginig to see a pattern here, similarly with Lord of the Rings.
Fellowship was a really good movie, and had it's great moments, but overall it was judged to be just good, not perfect.
Two Towers had even less fans - it had it's badass moments like the first movie, but PJ really overdid it in some scenes (The scenes with Ents were boring and dragged for way too long, the elves under the helms deep was such a major change from the books that it made a lot of funs dislike the movies).
The Return of the King was so epic it got a bazillion rewards including world record of oscars, and made up for the sins of two towers so much that the entire trilogy is considered timeless and great.

Hobbit was exactly the same. First movie was very decent, had it's minor mistakes, and overall was good but not perfect.
Desolation had it's epic moments like the first movie, but the overuse of Legolas and Tauriel that was a major change from the book annoyed a lot of fans, and Smaug not being able to catch a bunch of dwarfs in his own house also was overdone.
This movie, I think, can actually make up for the sins of Desolation and add to the already nice spotlight first movie had. If this is as epic and good as it looks, this can truely make hobbit trilogy something that will be remembered.

Comment: I don't understand why all the orcs ae CGI in this trilogy. Part of what made the LOTR series so enthralling was how real they seemed, how vile and grotesque the makeup made real people seem.¬† Now all I see is pixels that take away the immersive feel the LOTR trilogy provided.¬† I understand Smaug, the trolls, and the spiders all have to be computer generated, but switching from real people acting as orcs to CGI orcs was an absolutely dreadful idea.¬† Ian McKellen, the actor who plays Gandalf, broke down in tears on set in the first movie because he was acting by himself in front of a green screen, attempting to interact with nonexistent beings convincingly.¬† He then said "This is not why I became an actor."¬† I can see where you're coming from, Mr. McKellen.

Meaning it's just two different ways to tell the story. if you like action and drama, and want to cut all the little bits out like "what Bilbo ate" or "what smaugs breath smells like". and other minior things. the movie is for you. if you like to spend your time reading, and prefer to see the full detailed version in wording form using nothing but your imagination. the book is for you. both tolken and jacksons have told this tale in a great way.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
From what I've seen this looks like a decent movie, but I just can't forgive/forget all the dumb scenes from the previous two films. For example the river chase scene from DoS was absolutely asinine. A completely CG Bombur fights a dozen orcs while wearing a broken barrel as armor and wielding two axes. Bombur, an obese dwarf, then proceeds to jump into a moving barrel with PERFECT timing. I get that this is fantasy and 99% of the time I can let go, but that sequence of events hurt my brain.

Also not one of the dwarves from Thorin's crew is even half as cool as Gimli was. They're all pretty much interchangeable as far as I'm concerned. You think that during the course of three movies we'd get to know or like them more, but somehow Peter Jackson screwed that up. Instead we got a shitty love interest thing with Handsome Dwarf 1 and Elf Lady That Doesn't Exist. All of this seems familiar too...like somebody with a beloved franchise possibly set in space already tried the whole cashing in with half-ass prequel bullshit.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
The biggest problem people fail to see in movie directing/writing a story is that every story, regardless of what it is about or what it is going to be, needs an antagonist and a protagonist. In the book, everything fits perfectly, and is really well done. But to directly transfer it from a book to a movie wouldn't make a lot of sense. First off, there wouldn't be much excitement, it'd be mainly conversational scenes and such, and two, there isn't much of an antagonist until they get to the lonely mountain to Smaug. I get that "Holy shit, this isn't the fucking movie! This isn't what happened in the book, this movie fucking sucks!" It irks me too, and I'm a huge LOTR fan. But in terms of an audience, and appealing to audiences who have never read the Hobbit as well, it needs to be entertaining. It at least keeps your attention and doesn't bore you to death, and that's what a movie should do. A movie that is just downright laughable, (opinionated) most don't have the motivation to keep watching because it lacks intrigue.

Peter Jackson took a lot of these "extra" things from the appendixes of the book and put them into the movie. I'm bantering aimlessly, but people should understand that a movie can never be perfect, and always has flaws. As much as this makes me cringe, I still enjoy the movie regardless.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment: Does Peter Jackson understand what "based on " means. I think he thinks it means make up any old shit and insert it into one of the most beloved stories of recent times. Can`t begin to describe how disappointed this movie adaption has been, especially after the LOTR was done so well, with minimal movie licence excepted. This on the other hand feels like a exploitative rape of the book for its good bits with free reign to make up as much bollocks as he sees fit. J.R.R.Tolkien`s the Hobbit is a classic book and i wish it had been treated as such. Look forward to Jackson`s adaption of Dickens next.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
Personally, as someone who has read, seen, and/or enjoyed both the book and the two film versions of The Hobbit, I think the purists who complain about the films are, for the most part, being very selfish and unreasonable. Just because the movies don't look *exactly* like *your* imagination or match the source material word-for-word, that doesn't automatically mean the movies themselves are bad. Perhaps if someone made their own indie film version of the Middle Earth stories into a niche film for esoteric fantasy-geek communities, would they be satisfied with that? I imagine it might potentially turn into an underground cult favorite, but it wouldn't be nearly as successful as the current film adaptations (by the way, the films were created by an independent film studio, but they were fashioned to appeal to many different people, not just the readers who were already familiar with the stories. This allows non-readers and newcomers to discover the series as well as readers to enjoy the film, and all-in-all, I think the result has been largely positive.) Honestly, I don't think a lot of fans realise just how good this series has it: The Lord of the Rings and The Hobbit, if they were in the hands of another director and studio, would have probably suffered the same fate as the Dune series (wonderful books, but mediocre film), and that's just one example of a possible alternative outcome.
Some people are so busy picking apart the films for perceived negatives that they miss all the *good* things about the films. I myself take a more positive approach; instead of crying about every single detail that might be missing or changed, I like to either enjoy the books and films as separate stories, or enjoy each version as supplementary to one another. For example, the book is perfect the way it is, but the movies give each dwarf his own unique personality, and that to me adds more intrigue and layers to the story. Sure, the addition of Tauriel as Kili's romantic interest may not have been entirely necessary (and probably somewhat cliche as well), but I don't mind it personally, since it doesn't take away too much from the overall big picture, and I think it's kind of cute -- and yes, I do care enough about the series to be interested in what happens between them in the film. I won't give any spoilers here, but I am curious, not just about Tauriel and Kili, but also about the roles that Galadriel, Saruman, and Elrond will play in the movie, and of course, I want to see how the rest of the story will unfold on screen, because for me, making comparisons between the films and the book is actually fun and interesting. For that, I am very excited about the third film. I agree that, most times, books or source materials are better than the adaptations, but there are occasions when I actually prefer the adaptation over the source material (Forest Gump being one example), and sometimes, the adaptation is nearly equal in quality to the original,

but of course, that's for each individual to decide. As for myself, The Hobbit films are one of the most accurate adaptations to a book that I've ever seen, I mean, almost every event in the book was captured on film, and I for one happen to find that impressive.

People need to understand that books and films are very different mediums, and adaptations of either one will never match the source material 100%; Only in a perfect world would that ever happen. That being said -- especially compared to most adaptive interpretations -- the Peter Jackson adaptation to The Hobbit is actually *very* spot-on in it's accuracy of the plot and the atmosphere described in Tolkien's work, even with the added embellishments to the story (which, in my opinion, don't take away too much from the plot, especially since most of the embellishments are based on actual elements of the whole Middle Earth universe.)

As far as purists being selfish, well, the fact that they act as if the films were made *just* to cater to them is pretty self-centered, and they talk as if the differences between the pages and the film are somehow a personal attack against them or the author. I completely understand and agree with respecting the author's work, but in my opinion., the anti-film critics/fanatics are taking it too far. Some of the same people who complain about the films are probably the same ones who have been demanding a film adaptation for years, but when they finally get one, they just nit-pick and complain about the smallest details (sounds pretty ungrateful to me.) On top of that, some fans act high-and-mighty just because they prefer the books and hate the movies, and that's just pretentious and arrogant. There's just no pleasing some people, unfortunately...

Anyway, if you happen to be a person who personally didn't care for the films, then that's fine, because no one is forcing you to like the movies, and you can just stick with the books if you want. However, it's unreasonable, and childish even, to bemoan every little detail about the film and ruin the cinematic experience for others just because it didn't fit your exact expectations. I also get the impression that people compare the LotR trilogy films with the Hobbit films and expect them to look and sound exactly alike. Newsflash: The Hobbit was originally a children's book, and the tone of the book was more lighthearted and whimsical compared to the Lord of The Rings trilogy, even in book form, so would it not make sense that the Hobbit films would be more comical or whimsical as well? Also, the addition of comic relief in a film does not mean that the whole movie is crass, crude, or juvenile, and the comedy wasn't overdone either -- without it, the filmwould have been much too dark and solemn compared to the source material. I think people who believe that the film is terrible just because some parts of the movie happen to be comical are taking the story too seriously. Even Tolkien's sense of humor wasn't that dry or solemn... Besides, dwarves aren't supposed to be 'elegant' or 'polite', otherwise, they would look more like the elves! If all you got out of the Hobbit films were "burp jokes," then you've missed the point of the story entirely...

Also ridiculous is when fans complain, "There's too much CGI!" Obviously, some films overuse CGI and make it into a spectacle in itself, but that is not the case with the LotR and Hobbit films; the CGI is simply a special effect that enhances the visual storytelling. There's nothing inherently 'evil' about it. It is a tool, nothing more. Honestly, most people have no idea how difficult or painstaking it was to create realistic-looking visual effects without modern CGI or digital enhancement, and the advancement of digital/CGI technology would progress even more slowly if people like Peter Jackson did not push the limits of special effects. In fact, without the CGI, the films would be unrecognizable, and as a result of technological limitations, even *more* scenes would have to be cut out of the film, because the action or scenery would not be practically feasible! The Peter Jackson adaptations happen to make great use of practical effects -- the prosthetics, lighting, and make-up are excellent, and the miniatures, costumes, and sets are complex in craftsmanship, and they even filmed on location with beautiful landscapes as the backdrop! But practical effects can only go so far when filming a fantasy or science fiction of this magnitude (even Star Wars was produced with homemade computers to generate some of the special effects.) Not only that, but a project of this size would mean that if every single aspect of the film relied heavily on practical effects (with little to no digital or CGI enhancement), the budget would have to be astronomical to provide for all material tools. Without high-quality computer/digital enhancements, the films would look more like a BBC special instead of a grandiose cinematic adaptation, and to be honest, I think I would be a little more disappointed in the former option. The argument that the film has "too much CGI" happens to be a very subjective one, but then again, whether someone enjoys the films or the books is, in the end, subjective in itself.
And honestly, who could say anything unfavorable about the soundtrack? The music to the films are a lovely addition to the immersive fantasy epic, and it truly captures the magic of Middle Earth! [Okay, I can understand why some people weren't exactly pleased with the addition of Ed Sheeran's "I See Fire" for the end credits, but I don't think the song is that bad, and the song or artist choice could have been a lot worse, to be honest.]

How would J.R.R. Tolkien feel about the films? Well, no one can know for sure, since he has been deceased for decades, but as far as I can tell from biographies about him (and his reaction to a theatrical version of The Hobbit), I think that he would have been largely impressed. Sure, he would have frowned at some of the embellishments or changes to the plot or story, but I'm also convinced that all other aspects of the film would have amazed him greatly, and he would be pleased at how closely the films capture the magic of the epic story and the atmosphere. For example, prior adaptations of his work have interpreted the dwarves as garden gnome-like creatures, but the films more closely represent the rough-and-tough fighters that the dwarves were described as being in the Middle Earth universe. Also, prior adaptations have greatly simplified the plot of The Hobbit, whereas the film trilogy was able to tell the whole story, with room for embellishment, and a greater connection to the rest of the Middle Earth universe! [Most notably, the Rankin-Bass 1977 animation left out and changed many aspects of the story, not to mention that this version essentially killed off even more of the dwarves than the book itself! And in this version, the elves looked more like imps instead of the elegant, regal, and powerful people described in Tolkien's work and the Wingnut films. In some respects, the animated version was more accurate to the book, but for the most part, it was a rather simplistic, and arguably darker retelling of the story.]
Personally, I like to think of it in much the same way as a folk tale or piece of mythology: with each storyteller, the story changes little by little, and I like to think that's what happened here. I like to think that the people at Wingnut Films studio were as faithful to the book and its respective fictional universe as any large-scale film adaptation could get.
Anyway, I just think that a lot of fans could save themselves from unneeded stress if they would lighten up a bit and assess things more logically and with an open mind. If you didn't like the movies, that's fine and you are entitled to your own opinion, but that's no reason to try to ruin it for others. Regardless, I'll be enjoying the books *and* the films whether certain people like it or not. Life is too short to spend it on irrational bitterness and negativity. I think the films are great the way they are, and as much as I respect and admire Tolkien's work, I don't think I could have done it any better justice if I were a film director. I'm just grateful that someone has beautifully rendered a film series that has brought to life on the big-screen such awe-inspiring, legendary epics that will continue to inspire generations to come.

If someone told me that they didn't like the movie after watching it, I wouldn't freak out or insult them, or say things like, "You're just an ignoramus who doesn't appreciate good cinema!" What I would do instead is ask them, "Really? What is it about the film that you didn't like?" and depending on their answer, I would decide for myself if their reasons are valid or informed. If, for example, they explain specific things that displeased them, then their personal interpretation holds more support and I would respect their opinion even if I disagree.
But, if their answer is more like, "It was crap! Pure garbage! Nothing like the book at all! Peter Jackson should die!" well then of course, I'm less likely to take their opinion seriously.

My theory is that many fans, especially those who hold a lot of nostalgia for the book, are stuck in their own interpretation of the story, and as a result, they are unable to enjoy someone else's interpretation, no matter how technically well-done it may be. When someone goes into something with strong expectations rooted firmly in their own imagination, then that's a recipe for disappointment. Speaking for myself, though, I enjoy both book and film for what they are, and I personally find that the film does justice to the book very well. That's the thing about books though: everyone has their own interpretation. Even movies from original screenplays are open to a wide diversity of interpretation and opinion (especially when remakes/reboots are involved.) As I've stated before, if you don't particularly enjoy the films, that's *okay*, because we don't all have to like the same thing, but there's hardly any reason to be so negative or defensive about it. *If you like it, great! If not, that's fine too!* Just don't act like a pretentious snob or a rude jerk about your opinion, because the attitude really isn't necessary. In the end, whether or not someone appreciates or enjoys the films is a subjective matter, but at least try to have some informed logic or reason behind your opinion. That's all I'm saying.

Ah, but maybe my approach might be a bit too academic or scholarly to be realistic. Only in a perfect world would everyone express their opinion in an informed, mature, and civilized manner. Oh well, at least I can say that I've tried to be sensible on a subjective topic...

If you've made it to the end of my essay, then I thank you for your patience and attention. Hopefully, I've said enough to support my own opinion here.¬†¬†

Comment:
For all of who who complain that "This film series is being milked for all its worth,much like the STAR WARS universe"
All I can say is that if any of you have ever watch a film based novel that was completely 100% accurate and true the "the book" then please let me know!! The Shining film for example is literally 50% different than that of The Stephen King Novel. This book cannot be done in one film,It could have concluded during the sequel,but I highly doubt that any fans of what Peter Jackson has done to the myth of Tolkien's world will be dissapointed with a long drawn out franchise/trilogy. Hell I didnt think the Return of the King HAD ENOUGH endings. Read the book to understand that one. Adios.

Comment: ok while everyone in the comments goes on arguing about how bad this movie is I'm going to say my opinion. This movie looks awesome sure I wasn't the biggest fan of the first movie but it appears that Peter Jackson is learning from his mistakes and that the following movies are going to be better, the second movie is proof of that. Also the sets (although mostly CGI) looks pretty cool and the fight scenes look well choreographed. I like how amazing and in sync all the elves are when they draw their bows (I don't know if it's just me but it really pisses me off when something like that is done sloppily so this made me very happy). I am really excited for this and I hope that it will be as epic as the last Lord of the Rings movie. (I hope its not going to be the same thing just with different characters but it doesn't look like it will be so that's really good).

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment: Why is it that every director feels the need to mutilate a great story when adapting it to film? I understand most (not all) of the changes made to the LOTR trilogy, but this? So many unnecessary changes and additions that it warps the original story almost beyond recognition. The hobbit (and the LOTR trilogy) was more than just a story, it was THE story. Tolkien poured most of his life into them and created a world so rich and vast that I don't think anyone will ever surpass it. These movies in my opinion shit all over his work. Initially I was really excited when I heard Jackson wanted to include some elements from the Appendices and other works, but as soon as I watched the first movie I knew it was just a cash cow. These films reek of Hollywood, which to me is a huge disappointment as these stories have been a big part of me for a long time. Adding characters that didn't exist or were supposed to be dead, altering characters personalities, creating ridiculous love triangles, unnecessary action sequences, rushed character development (Bilbo), inaccurate portrayal of characters (Thorin is supposed to be really old, but instead got the Hollywood "pretty boy" makeover), and over the top special effects that make it look like I'm playing a video game. On top of that, it really fails to capture the feel of middle earth which is one thing I felt the LOTR trilogy did very well. I guess I could keep going but in the end I'm just ranting in the comments section on YouTube. Whatever, fuck you Hollywood, at least Tolkien's original works can't be touched.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
There is a lot of hate her on Jackson. :O To all people trying to be smart because they have read book for kids - Try to find out a bit more about Tolkien's universe and read more of his books that just lotr and hobbit, if you want to whine about it. Jackson takes into movie parts that weren't in the Hobbit book, like White Council, Dol Guldur, Sauron etc. because it happened in pretty much same time as a standard Hobbit plot, which Tolkien puts in other books. That is why it is 9 hours of movies. If PJ would just do exactly what The Hobbit book contains we would have movie for 10 yrs old, let's face it. This book is good, it is pleasant to read but it is not even close to lotr trilogy, as Tolkien was aware, yet Jackson managed to make it a very good prequel for lotr.
He obviously changes some facts, as he did in lotr (or just throwing them away) but in my opinion it is healthy for the movie. He made lotr much more dynamic than book really is. He had to miss some parts, but the choices were very good e.g. Bombadil - it would take a lot of time, yet brings nothing to the plot. Sometimes he even manages to express things better than even Tolkien did e.g. when Theoden gets healed by Gandalf - that is just pure genius depsite being totally out of the book.
The point is that he made the Hobbit much better that it could have been if someone made exactly as the book says and as a Tolkien fan I personally love it. My only problem is the way Gandalf is made - he is pretty much as powerful as Sauron, and deifnitely not less than Saruman, yet he seems like just an old guy who gets knocked everytime he is facing a real enemy. Even Galadriel looks superior to him, even though he is - as Maya - a higher level of being. Tolkien made him humble though so probably that's what Jackson is doing, but in my opinion he exaggerates a lot

Comment:
Hello everyone! Excuse my bad English, I live in Russia and I want to share something about the trailer and comment.

Peter Jackson - one of the best directors. I love his movies and for those who say that it spoils the book (by the way, I've read it too many times and I like it), I say:

The book and the film - incomparable things. When shooting movies always have to make any changes. Always. And more so, the film - it's not a literal retelling of the book. This is her adaptation. I do not deny that they have bad points, but the changes that have been made in "The Hobbit" for the most part for the better, in my opinion.

I like both books and movies. Many thanks for the trailer and all who took part in the filming of these movies!

There is not a single movie based on a book out there which is true to its story. Its really hard to film every page and dialog. Almost impossible so thats when you need to be creative and try to stick true to the books as best as possible. I truely believe mr Jackson did that.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
A lot of people probably don't know that Tolkien was VERY disappointed with the Hobbit after he completed the Lord of the Rings books. He thought it was so petty, considering the massive fantasy epic that came after it. He actually tried to rewrite the Hobbit to make it more epic, to make it feel more like part of the whole, but he failed to do so, in the end.

I feel that Jackson knows this, and is trying to turn the Hobbit into the fantasy epic that Tolkien couldn't, and I respect him for trying. After all, the original material will always be there for those to enjoy.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
In one of his letters, long before he sold the movie rights to his books (for a pittance, because he never expected anything to come of it), Tolkien wrote that if anyone was ever to make a Lord of the Rings movie, he (Tolkien) would either want full creative control, to make sure it was done right, or else he would want to be paid a *lot* of money.

Well Tolkien never lived to see the movies, but his estate is making boatloads of money, so Tolkien probably isn't spinning in his grave over the way Peter Jackson has butchered The Hobbit. But anyone who loves the book should be cringing right about now.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
Interested to see how it turns out, but I'm kind of disappointed that the movies are really different from the books. ¬†The Hobbit was originally a dark book, but Tolkien rewrote it to be a children's story after The Lord of the Rings was written. ¬†There's too much of a "ride" here and a lot of bs that never occured in the books. ¬†The thing that got me the most was that they're releasing BOOKS based on the MOVIE. ¬†It's ridiculous in my opinion. ¬†The movies themselves would have been fine as their own separate story, but releasing books rewritten to follow the movie is a bit too much.
I recognize that movies will be different, of course they have to be. ¬†Anyone remember the old cartoon version of The Hobbit? ¬†But still, the new books irritate me.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment: I for one have loved both films so far and am really looking forward to this one. Yes, Jackson turned a relatively short book in to three films. He also added a lot of stuff from the appendices, which I think is a huge improvement. Gandalf just saying 'well, I'm off' like he did in the book would be absolutely terrible. Legolas being in the films is just a logical thing. The love triangle I could do without, but I actually liked Tauriel's character. The dwarves are recognisable, and not just because of different colours of hats. Fighting Smaug might have been lengthy and not in the book, but it was entertaining enough for me. And at least we get to see things such as the White Council, the Ring having an influence on Bilbo, Gandalf's reasons for joining the quest. One of the main flaws of the book was introducing Bard at the exact time he was needed. So yes, I liked the Esgaroth politics, they clearly served a purpose. The barrel scene was just absolutely amazing. So yes, I actually like most changes Jackson has made to the Hobbit and practically all changes he made to The Lord of the Rings. (Tom Bombadil was the single most boring chapter in the entire trilogy in my opinion, and I was glad to see him go).

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
I wish people would stop complaining about the amount of CGI in the film or just the trailer.
Yes, there is a lot of CGI, but you can't expect them not to use it for creating armies, various creatures and scenery (the city of Erebor, laketown on fire etc) without using CGI. It would be impossible.
The elves do look the same if you pause the shot, they are CGI, it couldn't have hurt to get a few more actors, but it lasts about 2 seconds and elves (especially the minor elves) are known for being similar, moving together perfectly. There isn't much of a problem apart from people bothered about every. single. frame. You have to accept things can't always be real in films now, especially since this is such a long film.
You have to remember it is in 3D. They can't use the non-cgi tricks from Lotr, it doesn't WORK. So cgi is now the alternative for making height differences etc. which I think works well. Also, dressing up actors in full prosthetics is very difficult for them, but PETER JACKSON TRIED IT, BUT IT DIDN'T WORK SO THEY USED MOTION CAPTURE.
Many forget lots of extra content is taken out of the appendices not just the actual book of the hobbit, since many things are uneventful and unsuitable for movies.
If you read this I'm sorry I ranted.

Comment: COMMENTARY RUCKUS EXPLAINED: The movie industry feels the need to adjust with the technology/globalization age because it is "the future", even though the crew feels the need to film in New Zealand. Nonetheless, where did their 2 billion dollar budget go? I think this notion of "the future" is very misconstrued by the illusion of CGI's advancement to the entire film industry. When on the downside, CGI allows for an artificial substitution of real actors and costumiers. Sure, more revenue means people lose opportunities or preexisting jobs in the process, but hey, the upper class has got to be paid one way or another. THAT'S WHY THERE IS SUCH AN INEQUALITY GAP AND MISTRUST BETWEEN THE UPPER AND THE MERGED MIDDLE/POOR CLASSES. The "traditional" lifestyle might've been less appealing, but this thoughtless adaption to technology is ruining our economic infrastructure by marginalizing the lower classes. Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment: There's a psychological phenomenon that occures when something gets to be so popular, the next step is to hate it. Like many social sciences, they're not exact. However, the likely reason for this is because people don't like feeling that they're just part of the crowd. So a person may like something like a movie, book, song, etc. Then more people start to like it. Eventually the thing gets so popular the person who originally liked it convinces them self (subconsciously) that they hate it because they want to feel that they're more of an independent thinker. This often coincides with a cognitive biased where whenever a person is convinced of one thing, they dismiss any evidence that challenges their opinion and only excepts what supports it.

Comment:
Yeah, I'm sure I'll see it just to complete the series, but I'm sure it'll be way overdone with too much extra crap added rather than just telling the story. That's been the problem with this three movie Ode to Peter Jackson's Ego. Couldn't we just have had one or maybe two movies telling the story from the book instead of having a mish mash from other sources and implied happenings tossed in like some frou frou gormet salad?

The Lord of the RIngs movies were good precisely because they mostly followed the books. Peter Jackson is a great film maker, but he's not a great fantasy writer, thus the author of the books these movies are supposed to be based on is J.R.R. Tolkien and not him. He'd do better sticking closer to the source material. Even with the slightly cheesy animation, the Rankin Bass movie version of The Hobbit was a more coherent telling of the actual story.¬†

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
I have waited for the Hobbit to be made into a feature film since I first read it as a child. Now, I wish it had never happened. Jackson completely and utterly ruined it, from the tone to adding characters in that weren't even in the book. This could have been done with two movies at the most, but three??? People talk about how Jackson and his writers are "The perfect people to adapt this book"... I wonder if they even read it, it was not this dark, not at all! Even in the first film, when Bilbo faced off against that albino Orc ( also not in the book ), that would never have happened! The Barrel ride? Ridiculous!!! The whole point was that Bilbo used stealth to smuggle the dwarves out unnoticed! Complete and utter Hollywood garbage. This was Peter's chance to do another LOTR, pure and simple. So much talk about doing this for the fans, I disagree... more like selling out. Maybe in enough time, someone will come back and adapt it properly, and not with their self-important posturing.

I had real faith in Jackson, but to tell the truth I wonder now how he managed to do so well with the LOTR trilogy.¬†

Yet another adaptation that fell short. I hope he is never allowed to touch another Tolkien story again.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
¬†Will everyone ,for the love of God, stop complaining about the CGI. When The Lord of the Rings ended Peter Jackson said that, "This is the end." Which means they were not going to make Hobbit movies. But every fan of them was pleading for Hobbit movies and they heard us. So Peter Jackson went and made The Hobbit Trilogy.
¬†
¬†So instead of complaining that it has CGI in it and that he added a few things to it, we should all just be thankful that he even made Hobbit movies because he wasn't going to in the first place. Because all of you pleaded to him to make them. So when he actually makes them you all wine about them.

¬†I believe true fans of The Hobbit and Tolkien's works would like The Hobbit of what it is and its beautiful story and theme. And if they add a few extra characters or if they add some CGI to some stuff, so what. It does not ruin the story in anyway. All of these complainers and what they are saying are going against everything Tolkien believed, of what he put in his stories and what he wanted for the world. ¬† The Hobbit can't be and look like The Lord of the Rings because of the 13 years or so they are separated. For me I am very excited to see this wonderful last movie.

¬†So please, just be thankful for these wonderful movies and just enjoy what The Hobbit is and that we even got any movies at all. ¬† ¬† ¬†¬†

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment: All right.. but I can't see the Dwarven army - only Elves and Orcs. I've seen enough of that in LOTR movies.. lots and lots of Elves and Orcs. And here we should have at least 500 Dwarven Warriors from Iron Hills - grim, tough, stout short dudes heavily clad in iron mail and boots. Not some merry fairies but serious, battle worn killers with heavy axes- no less than portrayed by Tolkien and he made it pretty clear that these dudes mean business. If the show will be run by the Elves again with their sneaky ninja ways and shiny, gay armor, I'm going to explode on my sit in movie theater.. Of course - I've got nothing against Elves and the battle is not what attracted me to the story, I wish there was less combat, more wandering and adventures - just like in the book. But I understand that what's cool to read may not necessarily work on the screen. However, this is an adaptation, core facts have to be preserved and since the movie's called The Battle of Five Armies and the Dwarves are in the center of the story, I expect that to be respected.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment: Everyone needs to realize,¬†especially Jackson, that some stories are not just material to manipulate and make money from.¬† When you have a classic, especially one that needs -no- embellishment, you just don't monkey with it.¬† Of course the people who grew up with this are going to be frustrated.¬† Liberties are not always to be taken.¬† That being said, of course I'll watch it.¬† And probably like it - not love it.¬† Unlike Jackson and many others, I won't have to meet/greet Tolkien, Burroughs and many other writers¬†in the afterlife - and get a hard slap in the face or a major beat down.¬† If not for the 'canon'¬†fans, none of you would be watching these movies;¬†they'd not be¬†imbedded in our society.¬† So remember that, the next time you think badly of us.¬† I feel sorry for the fool who attempts to remake Gone with the Wind, however¬†the mainstay crowd of that piece are nearly gone..¬† Will still be a shame to see though.¬† I still prefer the Ralph Bakshi versions of the Tolkien films overall, even with the poor animation....¬† At least I don't have to see any sequels to John Carter - even if made, I'll never go see them.¬† Disney/Staunton are more interested in resurrecting Dory from Finding Nemo .....¬† the entire John Carter team needs to be imprisoned for life with no chance of¬†parole - along side long time Burroughs fans.¬† Almost as bad as the first Tarzan remake with Bo Derek....

Comment:
In the Desolation of Smaug trailer, there was also loads of bad CGI. But fortunately, the film itself was much better. Many of the shots in the trailer were completely redone for the actual film (see comparison videos on youtube). The colours and contrast in the trailer are overly dramatic, which is not the case in the film.
Also, 48fps 3D makes the CGI stand out less, because the geometry of CGI and live action are so consistent.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment: Just pause at 0:32... Look at the elves. WHY DO THEY HAVE TO MAKE EVERYTHING CGI FOR FUCKS SAKE??? Is it really so hard to get real actors with real costumes and really facial expressions? This whole picture is computer generated, there is nothing real about it, no tree, no mountain no face and I guess thats how 90% of the movie will look like. You don't have to fly all the way to New Zealand for this bullshit. This is no freaking computer game, this is supposed to be a movie that many of us have waiter for a long long time. Its just disappointing as fuck to see this, even Viggo Mortensen said it. I understand if you make a Balrog CGI but can't you at least get 10 elves in costumes for the front row? Is this to much to ask for a 2 Billion Dollar Budged?? I'm just glad LOTR was made 12 years earlier where it was still cheaper to put on costumes sometimes and use real actors, if it was made today by Peter he would have ruined it as well with his fetish for new technology. ¬†

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
The character shots look pretty good, but the CGI is really awful, and over-abundant. I hope they'll fix it until the premiere, since it's only a month. Jackson's gotten way too greedy with it, he's using it for stuff like goblins/orcs (which is better using people in make-up) and even on locations (he puts green screens around the actors to use the same surroundings that's behind the green screens, but slightly to the left or right) And wow, all that filler crap. I feel that the movies suffered going from two to three movies, because it meant that Jackson had to come up with even more fanfiction, and fast too, which resulted in for example the dreadful Dragon vs Dwarves scenes in the last one.

Also it's sad that you apparently can't critizice the movies/trailers without being called trolls by people violently defending Jackson, and I feel that the only do that because he also did LOTR.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
The music to me feels somewhat reminiscent to "Requiem for a Dream" in the beginning. 

I honestly can't wait for the movie, I'm going to re-read the book before the movie comes out. I know Peter Jackson deviated a lot from the book, but I don't care, the lord of the rings films deviated a lot from the novels as well. Though The Hobbit trilogy doesn't meet the heights of the Lord of the Rings, it has become a great blockbuster with fun action and emotion story arcs, therefore, they are still great, fun and enjoyable films to me. I will probably sob at the end of the movie, I grew up with Middle - Earth, my first theatre experience was when I was  5 and " The Fellowship of the Ring" came out, my parents couldn't find me a baby sitter so they tagged me along, I watched the movie with them and I loved it!  I read all the books later when I was older, like around my freshman year! But overall, I'm excited for this! The adrenaline is just too much right now! Lol

Comment: To the more diehard Tolkien fans, forgive my ignorance, but did the Elves have ANY kind of legitimate claim for the treasure? The Dwarves certainly did (Birthright), and the humans kind of sort of could make a claim for a small share of it to help rebuild their town (Especially since the Dwarves' actions provoking Smaug were what got their village destroyed, sort of like if you accidentally broke a neighbor's window and paid them the money to replace it) and compensate them for their generosity towards Thorin's company, but it seems to me (And again, forgive me if I'm wrong) like the Elves just heard there was a lot of gold there and got greedy.

Fun to watch and smart movies.They aren't Lord of the Rings but definitely a solid 8/10.¬†

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment: Everyone has a right to an opinion and I / you have the right not to listen to it. Tolkien wrote this in 1937; my guess is he would be pretty excited to see how this epic world he envisioned more than 77 years ago became the journey Peter Jackson re-invisioned for the screen. If nothing else, he would probably be blown away by Jackson's 20 year commitment to breathing life into those pages and The Lord of the Rings. And he would probably invite you along to enjoy the ride and ask you to reserve judgment until the end of the experience. A movie will never have the same impact as the personal movie you envisioned when reading the pages of a beloved book. Why not enjoy another's journey as well as your own? This is a great trailer.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
I've got to admit that there might be a bit too much CGI in this trailer (did all the elves and orcs had to be CG on the close ups ?).

But god damn it, when you look at it, the CGI is just great ! I mean Erebor feels real as hell (both from inside and outside), the landscapes are stunning, it is impossible to tell wether some sets are extended with the green screen tech or not and if so, what part of the set is real and what part is fake (which is, I think, the main difference with the Star Wars prequels regarding CGI), the wide army shots look 100x times better than those from LotR, Laketown was impressive in DoS (looks even better when burning) and hell even Azog looks stuningly realistic and scary on the close-up we get from him !

So right, the CGI might be overused for characters, but for landscapes, wide shots, epic shots, set extensions... it looks sooooo great ! I'd go as far as to say that the CG version of many sets looks better and more realistic than the models we had in LotR (Laketown, one of the most realistic CG cities ever made, Rivendell looks better in AUJ then in LotR and Erebor is just stunning... Looks more realistic and has way more details than Moria !)¬†

All this to say : please guys stop complaining about CGI, it brings soo much into the movie !

I thought the first one was mostly boring and the second one was ok but this makes the third one look like it's going to be EPIC!!!!! That scene where Kili is screaming at Thorin made me stop breathing in shock, and I love the sound of disappointment in Dwalin's voice when he says "you cannot even see what you have become." This movie looks like it's going to have me crying from all the emotions, and that's awesome in a horrible way! I will be crying, but it will be from watching such an awesome Middle-Earth movie. I really hope they give Tauriel time to shine before they kill her, because she's one of my favorite characters in this trilogy. Her, Kili, Bilbo, and Legolas are all awesome.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
I have genuinely mixed feelings about this trailer. The character development looks absolutely amazing (especially Thorin's), I felt emotionally connected with all of these characters simply after watching a 2:33 video. The battle scenes look intense. The scene with Gandalf/Saruman/Galadriel/Elrond/SAURON! looks amazing! The whole film looks a masterpiece. But the one thing that makes me feel sad is... the fact that this is the last time Middle-Earth will appear on the big screen. Now, I know this sounds overly nerdy and lame but... that's the only thing I could think of when watching this!

My favourite story is finally coming to an end.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
I hate people who complain about movies not being like the books they were made after to be to busy nerd raging to understand how movies are made. Jackson said originally NONE of the movies would be exactly like the books because it would be impossible to fit it into a movie unless you want to a billion movies. Which I wouldn't mind but to the normal movie goer they don't want to see The Hobbit: Part 23. BTW I am a massive LOTR/Hobbit fan.

So I accept that almost all movies based on books (or anything else) aren't often accurate. Just like many don't like that Transformers (for example) aren't like the series. I don't mind. They are meant to be brainless action flicks. I'm just glad to see Transformers on a big screen no matter the changes or how cheesy the story is.¬†

Which is why I say some things in summary:
1. If you don't like it, don' see it.
2. Unless you can make a better version of it then be grateful it even became a film.¬†

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment: Everyone's ragging on the CGI. I think it looks great. CGI never bothered me, it stretches what a regular person is capable of doing. An example of why I sometimes prefer CGI is Underworld. Granted it's an older series, but the werewolves in the earlier films were just people in kind of crappy wolf costumes. Mouths didn't move, claws flailed around like rubber, it totally pulls you out of the immersive feel of the movie. Granted it's my personal opinion that this CGI looks good and it works for me, which may not be the case for everyone. But could you imagine building a cave troll suit and having it be partly mechanical, puppet controlled facial expressions, or something. It would be clunky, noticeable, and couldn't get the wear and tear that CGI characters go through.

Title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies - Official Main Trailer [HD]
Comment:
Now I see what Jackson meant about this being the most emotional and biggest of the 6 films. I mean I tear up almost every time I finish watching the LOTR trilogy, but I was internally tearing up just at this trailer. Some of that dialogue was freaking emotional. As the first trailer was a little bit of a let down for me, this exceeded my expectations. My only problem is that some of the CGi looks unfinished but I know that they aren't completely done with the post production yet so it'll probably look better in the final film. Can't wait.

All I can say is "We come to it at last, the great trailer of our time."
